plants.name: Crocus vernus
plants.description: A perennial flowering plant that often signals the start of spring, Crocus vernus produces cup-shaped flowers that emerge from the soil while snow may still be on the ground.
plants.location: Temperate regions of Europe and North America
plants.funFact: Crocus flowers were historically used to produce saffron dye from certain species closely related to Crocus vernus.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A hardy evergreen perennial that blooms in late winter, often around Christmas time, the Christmas Rose has large white to pinkish flowers that brighten shady, woodland gardens.
plants.location: Alps and mountainous regions of Europe
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Christmas Rose is not a true rose and is poisonous if ingested.

plants.name: Mahonia aquifolium
plants.description: An evergreen shrub native to the Pacific Northwest, it blooms with bright yellow flower clusters in late winter and early spring, attracting early pollinators.
plants.location: Northwest United States and Southwest Canada
plants.funFact: Oregon Grape's berries are edible and were traditionally used by Native Americans to make a blue dye.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: A popular ornamental shrub known for its large, showy flowers that bloom in winter and early spring, thriving in temperate climates.
plants.location: East Asia and cultivated worldwide in similar climates
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica flowers are edible and sometimes used in teas, but the plant contains caffeine and should be consumed in moderation.
